name: Inconceivable
description:
Leanne Moden really should know better. After all, her poems have been upsetting people in magazines and anthologies, as well as causing consternation at spoken word gigs, for around two years now. 

Leanne has a clinical obsession with rhyming couplets, and her playful, comedic verse has been described as 'just the right side of filthy', 'completely unexpected' and 'fucking hilarious'.

'Inconceivable' is Leanne's first collection of poetry, and deals with all the important aspects of modern living. From the decline of the Goth population and the rise of the feline con artist, to the need to dress appropriately for adverse weather conditions and the importance of maintaining your follicle integrity, Leanne's poems are fun, funny and always surprising.

name: 28 Sonnets Later
description:
“The whole collection is bursting with modern life ... 
It’s immediate, relevant and has a great sense of fun!” - Luke Wright


In February 2012, four poets challenged themselves to write a sonnet a day. 
28 Sonnets Later is the result.

Andy Bennett is a poet, comedian, and idiot. His first collection of poetry, Daddy, What’s A Poet? is also published by deadbeat press.

Leanne Moden is a performance poet from Wisbech, and was recently voted second best poet in the Fens (it's a small circle.) She performs poetry around the East of England and mainly eats cheese sandwiches.

Russell J Turner is an actor, poet and broadcaster based in Norwich. He survives solely on a diet of caffeine and nicotine, which he metabolises into useful nutrients. 

Adam Warne puts the try into poetry. His poems have been published online and in The Rialto and as a stand-up comedian he's performed across East Anglia.

name: Daddy, What's A Poet?
description:
Andy Bennett has been performing stand up comedy and poetry for half a decade, around Norwich and at Fringes and Festivals across the country. His wilfully shambolic style belies a cerebral and acerbic wit, and an honest and celebratory approach to life and performance. Andy writes poems that, two hundred years ago, would have got him rusticated. Andy also likes the word ‘rusticated’ a little more than a man should.

“Daddy, What’s A Poet?” is Andy’s first collection of poetry, and contains a mixed and satirical selection of poems that combine Andy’s huge historical geekery with a desire to understand how the lessons of history can be applied to 21st Century Britain. There’s also a fair bit in there about drugs, and some really groan-worthy cartoons.

32pp
